result.execSummary: Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

03:33 PM Defendant Jason A Hoover  #353489 in court.  Lester H Liptak appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Heard along with 15CF114, 16CF170.  DE asking the court to approve a occupational DL.  DE had contact with DOT and was informed he will need paperwork from the court as he is a habitual offender to obtain an occupational DL.  Court instructs DE to contact DOT after release from prison and obtain the paperwork needed then make another court date for this matter. DE also requesting an Order for Half Priced Ignition Interlock, court will grant this request.  An Order will be prepared.

Defendant Jason A Hoover in court.  James D Babbitt appeared for the State of Wisconsin telephonic.  Heard along with 16CF170.  DE appears without counsel, has contacted the PD office for representation but has not heard back from them.  DE believes his counsel from Dunn County is working on a deal with all counties (also has 2 matters pending in Pepin County, one in Dunn).  The court will adjourn these cases until Tuesday when PD will be here to assess availability.  The State wishes to proceed with ordering bond, asking for a high cash bond.  The court will order a $5000.00 cash bond, based on the number of pending OWI cases.  $5000.00 cash bond,   Defendant is not to consume or possess alcohol.  Do not enter premises where alcohol is primary business, any bars taverns or liquor stores or any other establishment where the primary purpose is the sale of alcohol.  DE may not be anywhere alcohol is present.  Set for 12-06-16 @ 9:00AM, Adj Init App. on both cases.
